stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on importing and implementing a large number of assets from artist Biobak into a new disco-themed level. This involved fixing bugs, adjusting material properties, and tackling significant technical challenges, including running out of RAM and programming a custom real-time lighting system for a specific object. He also showcased and explained his new, deterministic collision engine designed to improve player control.

development_findings.summary: A core design goal is to make movement predictable. Kaze implemented a new collision routine to ensure Mario consistently sticks to walkable slopes, eliminating the random behavior caused by sub-frame positioning in the original engine.
development_findings.quote: I want to remove quarter frame precision from the player's mind. Like, I don't want the player to think about their quarter frames when they play my game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identifies a fundamental engine limitation regarding landing precision (losing movement based on sub-frame timing) that cannot be fixed without a complete overhaul of the game's physics, which is not feasible.
development_findings.quote: This is unsolvable without introducing proper delta time physics in Mario 64, I believe. Or by rerunning Mario's behavior multiple times. Both of which would have pretty huge consequences.

development_findings.summary: The project ran into the N64's RAM limit. Kaze resolved it by strategically moving smaller assets into an 'emergency memory pool' to reduce memory fragmentation and free up space in the main pool.
development_findings.quote: I think this pushed us into out of memory range... The emergency memory pool is a small memory pool. So if you have a lot of small data you can just chuck it in there to prevent any fragmentation of the main pool.

development_findings.summary: A split-screen multiplayer mode is being considered. The implementation would involve vertical screen splitting, which would result in smaller frame buffers and paradoxically free up more RAM for game assets.
development_findings.quote: If we do add multiplayer the way we would want it to work is there would be two screens on top of each other and a little bit would be cut off... which means smaller frame buffers which means more memory actually for that.

development_findings.summary: To accommodate an artist's detailed vertex-colored model while still having dynamic lighting, Kaze programmed a custom solution to calculate per-vertex lighting on the CPU at runtime, merging artistic and technical needs.
development_findings.quote: Because Biobak wants his vertex colors on the apple, and I want my shadows on the apple. So we compromise by computing the fucking shadows on the CPU in real time.

development_findings.summary: The game is approaching the 64MB ROM size limit, prompting plans to optimize space by removing all unused assets from the original Super Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: We're actually also pretty close to the ROM limit. If you look at this, 60 megabytes. Dude, we have 4 more megabytes.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's custom engine handles transparent textures better than the original SM64 engine because he fixed an issue where the original engine rendered transparent decal layers in the wrong order.
development_findings.quote: If you did this on the Mario 64 engine, it would look like dog shit. Because the layers are in the wrong order on Mario 64.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that player movement in a platformer should be deterministic and intuitive, leading him to rewrite major parts of the collision engine to eliminate randomness caused by engine quirks like 'quarter frame precision'.
context_findings.quote: I feel like there never should be any randomness in Mario's movement.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a personal design principle of staying within the N64's original 64MB ROM limit, viewing it as a creative constraint that honors the original hardware.
context_findings.quote: If you go beyond 64 megabytes you're going beyond what the original Nintendo 64 developers worked with and like that just feels like cheating.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's philosophy on learning new skills is to first achieve technical proficiency with the tools (like Blender's hotkeys) as a prerequisite to being able to effectively express creativity and have fun.
context_findings.quote: My approach to blender was very much not have fun, but rather like... learn your tools at first and then you get to have fun.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, share a playful, joking dynamic, as seen in his recurring, sarcastic complaints about her giving him a haircut.
context_findings.quote: I'm abused by my wife. It's called a haircut.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses genuine excitement and affection for his robotic lawnmower, which is currently being repaired.
context_findings.quote: You guys know the Gary Come Home song from Spongebob, that's how I feel about my lawnmower.

context_findings.summary: The project is considering a presentation at F3, a fan game expo. Zeina has already created a potential thumbnail for it.

biobak.summary: Biobak's new Poochie model is significantly more optimized (59 triangles) than the previous version.
Kaze had to modify the material properties (combiners) on some of Biobak's models, like a rotating stone ball, to add dynamic shading so they wouldn't look flat when moving.
biobak.quote: The way you had the combiner setup made me think you wanted maybe an additive combiner so we could...

biobak.summary: Biobak's use of detailed vertex colors on a spinning apple model prompted Kaze to develop a complex, real-time CPU-based lighting solution to have both vertex colors and dynamic shadows.
Kaze notes that Biobak's new, more optimized models have helped reduce the game's overall RAM usage.
The team's workflow, such as keeping objects in separate blend files, is partially dictated by the need to accommodate Biobak's computer hardware.
biobak.quote: Well, if they weren't the same, Biobak wouldn't be able to work on this at all, considering his spoopy computer.

zeina.summary: Zeina is involved in the project's external presentation, having designed a new thumbnail for a potential F3 showcase.
zeina.quote: Oh, she sent me a new F3 thumbnail. This is kind of a banger.

zeina.summary: Kaze jokingly defers an issue with a model's rigging to Zeina, highlighting her role as the team's animator.
zeina.quote: Why is the arm so far back? Whatever, that's a problem for the animator.

zeina.summary: Kaze and Zeina have a playful back-and-forth in the stream chat, with Kaze making recurring jokes about his new haircut.
zeina.quote: Yeah, that's how mean she is to me and I bet just for me saying this she's gonna shave off the last bit of hair tonight.

zeina.summary: Kaze speculates that an older version of the Flower Guy enemy model may have been created by Zeina.

key_stories.title: Eliminating Randomness in Slope Movement
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified that random outcomes from walking on slopes in Mario 64 were frustrating and unintuitive. He rewrote the collision system to be more predictable, ensuring Mario consistently sticks to slopes and removing the need for players to worry about 'quarter frame' exploits or inconsistencies.
key_stories.challenge: In the original Mario 64, walking off a sloped edge results in random behavior: Mario might stick to the slope or fly off, depending on sub-frame timing. This makes movement feel inconsistent and unpredictable for players.
key_stories.process: Kaze created a new, 'nearly continuous' collision routine. This system actively checks the path ahead and ensures Mario's position is correctly snapped to the ground, eliminating the ambiguity of the original engine's discrete, frame-by-frame checks.
key_stories.outcome: The new collision system makes slope interaction completely consistent. Mario now always sticks to walkable slopes, providing players with reliable and intuitive control without needing to understand obscure engine mechanics.
key_stories.key_quote: I want to remove quarter frame precision from the player's mind. Like, I don't want the player to think about their quarter frames when they play my game.

key_stories.title: The Compromise for the Spinning Apple's Shadow
key_stories.summary: A conflict arose between an artist's desire for detailed vertex colors and a programmer's need for dynamic lighting on a spinning model. Kaze resolved this by programming a custom, real-time, CPU-based lighting system for the object, representing a significant technical compromise to achieve the desired artistic vision.
key_stories.challenge: Biobak created a spinning apple model with detailed vertex colors. However, the standard N64 lighting used for dynamic shadows would override these colors. Without lighting, the spinning apple would look flat and fake.
key_stories.process: Kaze implemented a custom real-time lighting solution on the CPU. For each frame, the code takes the level's light vector, transforms it into the apple's local rotating space, calculates the lighting for each vertex, and applies it via the alpha channel, effectively creating a software-based lighting system for one object.
key_stories.outcome: The compromise was a success. The apple now features both Biobak's detailed vertex coloring and smooth, dynamic shadows that rotate correctly with the object, satisfying both artistic and technical requirements.
key_stories.key_quote: Because Biobak wants his vertex colors on the apple, and I want my shadows on the apple. So we compromise by computing the fucking shadows on the CPU in real time.
